items.title: Monument to a City
items.abstract: Where I saw Paris in D.C., my French in-laws saw neo-Classical run wild.

items.title: Country Returns to City Radio: After 17 Years, a Home in New York
items.abstract: Nash FM, at 94.7 FM, will fill a conspicuous gap in the city’s media market and serve as a flagship for a multimedia engine that will promote the “country lifestyle.”

items.title: In a Suburban Home, Some Unwelcome Guests
items.abstract: In Edward Albee’s Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, the suburban characters illustrate the paralyzing fear of existence and the fragility of connections.

items.title: Suburban Perfection, With Warts
items.abstract: “The Playroom” is a drama about a seemingly ideal family in the 1970s that has several cracks below the surface.

items.title: Quest for a Little-Known Suburban Lizard
items.abstract: An expedition to study the variable-scaled anole in the Andean uplands of Colombia begins with a less than scientific challenge: dealing with traffic.

items.title: Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out Snow
items.abstract: In New York, the National Weather Service said 26.8 inches of snow had fallen on Central Park by midnight, making this the city’s second-biggest snowstorm since 1869.

items.title: Suburban Dreaming in Woodstock
items.abstract: In her winter rental, a Brooklynite fantasizes about effortless parking, tire swings and home canning in a country house.

items.title: When State Control Damages a City
items.abstract: The crisis in Flint raises serious questions about how and when state-appointed emergency managers should intervene.

items.title: ‘Dream Cities,’ by Wade Graham
items.abstract: The ideas and structures that created today’s cities, and the architects and planners who implemented them.
keywords: Dream Cities: Seven Urban Ideas That Shape the World (Book)

items.title: What Happened to the Great Urban Design Projects?
items.abstract: American infrastructure should be about awe. Instead, it’s deferred home maintenance on a massive scale.

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: Massapequa Park, N.Y.: A Homey Village Amid Suburban Sprawl
items.abstract: Buyers will find a range of options in this village on the South Shore of Long Island, from modest starter homes to large waterfront houses with docks.

items.title: Why the Amazon Deal Collapsed: A Tech Giant Stumbles in N.Y.’s Raucous Political Arena
items.abstract: The company, long accustomed to deferential treatment from localities, badly misjudged how it would be received in the city, according to dozens of interviews.

items.title: Paul George, at Peace in Oklahoma City, Reels In a Career Year
items.abstract: George, a star forward for the Thunder, is playing his best basketball in his second season for a team many thought would only be a pit stop in his career.

items.title: Congestion Pricing in Manhattan, First Such Plan in U.S., Is Close to Approval
items.abstract: After years of hesitation, the governor and lawmakers reached agreement on the plan, which would help to provide badly needed financial assistance for mass transit.

items.title: Dennis Smith, Firefighter Who Wrote Best Sellers, Dies at 81
items.abstract: “Report From Engine Co. 82” was the first of his 16 books. He also started Firehouse magazine and was the founding chairman of the New York City Fire Museum.

items.title: After Urban Flight, Corporate Campuses Add a Taste of the City
items.abstract: Suburban headquarters are being redesigned to add more amenities that will integrate better with their communities and attract the skilled workers.

items.title: How Josh Mandel, Son of Suburban Ohio, Became a Right-Wing Warrior
items.abstract: The Senate candidate was a rising Republican when he abandoned his moderate roots. Now, those who have watched his transformation wonder if his rhetoric reflects who he really is.

items.title: In Nashville, a Gerrymander Goes Beyond Politics to the City’s Core
items.abstract: Tennessee was long known for a brand of moderate Southern politics. Nashville, a blue island in a red state, is finding that the old rules no longer apply.

items.title: Plainfield, N.J.: A Diverse City With Historic Housing
items.abstract: The city’s ornate Victorian homes are more affordable than those in surrounding areas. But that’s only one of the reasons that people move here.
